title: Masculine Plurals (-os -> -oi)
reading_greek:
GROUP 1: -OS NOUNS
Ο δρόμος (Student) -> Οι δρόμοι (Students)
Ο φίλος (Friend) -> Οι φίλοι (Friends)
Ο άνθρωπος (Human) -> Οι άνθρωποι (Humans)

GROUP 2: -AS/-IS NOUNS
Ο άντρας (Man) -> Οι άντρες (Men)
Ο πατέρας (Father) -> Οι πατέρες (Fathers)
Ο χάρτης (Map) -> Οι χάρτες (Maps)
Ο μαθητής (Student) -> Οι μαθητές (Students)

ACCUSATIVE PLURAL
Βλέπω τους δρόμους. (I see the streets.)
Βλέπω τους φίλους. (I see the friends.)
Βλέπω τους άντρες. (I see the men.)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: MASCULINE PLURALS (Page 44)

1. THE RULE OF -OS: Most masculine nouns end in -os. 
   - In Plural, -os becomes -oi. (Dromos -> Dromoi).

2. THE RULE OF -AS/-IS: Nouns ending in -as or -is follow a different pattern.
   - In Plural, they both become -es. (Antras -> Antres, Xartis -> Xartes).

3. ACCUSATIVE: When they are objects (after verbs/prepositions):
   - -os nouns become -ous. (Tous dromous).
   - -as/-is nouns become -es. (Tous antres - same as Nominative!)
audio_script:
Plurals! Let's multiply our nouns. 

For Masculine nouns, we have two main groups.

Group 1: Words ending in -os (The big group). 
'O Dromos' becomes 'Oi Dromoi'. 
The 'os' turns into 'oi'. 

Group 2: Words ending in -as or -is. 
'O Antras' becomes 'Oi Antres'. 
'O Xartis' becomes 'Oi Xartes'. 
They both turn into 'es'.

Careful! 'Oi dromoi' (masculine) sounds exactly like 'Oi dromoi' (fem plural article? No, wait). 
Actually, the article 'Oi' is the same for Masculine and Feminine in plural. 
'Oi dromoi' (The streets - Masc). 
'Oi ores' (The hours - Fem). 
This is why you must know the Gender from the singular!
